clinical_study.brief_title: Understanding How Ketamine Brings About Rapid Improvement in OCD
clinical_study.official_title: NMDAR Modulation As a Therapeutic Target and Probe of Neural Dysfunction in OCD

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to understand how ketamine brings about rapid improvement in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) symptoms.

detailed_description.textblock: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a chronic and disabling disorder that costs the economy over $2 billion annually and represents a significant public health problem. This study aims to build on our discovery that a potent NMDA receptor antagonist, ketamine, has rapid (in hours) and robust therapeutic effects in OCD. The proposed projects test the acute mechanism of action of ketamine at the level of molecules, circuits, and network synchrony to determine how NMDA receptor antagonism modifies the underlying pathology of OCD to relieve repetitive thoughts and behaviors.

study_design_info.masking: Double Blind (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: improvement in the severity of OCD symptoms as measured by the Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (YBOCS)

secondary_outcome.measure: regional gamma-aminobutyric acid, glutamate/glutamine levels derived from 3T Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy

arm_group.description: OCD patients in this arm will receive 0.5mg/kg of ketamine - one single infusion
OCD patients in this arm will receive 0.045mg/kg of midazolam - one single infusion

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for participants with OCD:
- age 18-60
- Primary diagnosis of OCD
- Sufficient severity of OCD symptoms
- ability to tolerate a treatment-free period
- capacity to provide informed consent
Inclusion criteria for healthy controls:
- ages 18-60
- capacity to provide informed consent
Exclusion criteria for participants with OCD:
- Psychiatric or medical conditions that make participation unsafe
- pregnant or nursing females
- concurrent use of any medications that might increase the risk of participation (e.g. drug interactions)
- presence of metallic device or dental braces
Exclusion criteria for healthy controls:
- any current or lifetime psychiatric diagnosis
- pregnant or nursing females
- major medical or neurological problem
- presence of metallic device or dental braces
